did.abstract: Vito Marcantonio (1902-1954), who received his law degree from New York University in 1931, was an American Labor Party leader and U.S. Congressmen representing East Harlem, New York, 1935-1937 (as a Republican), and 1939-1951 (American Labor Party). Contains six United States Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) files obtained under the Freedoom of Information Act and one U.S. State Department document.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
relatedmaterial.p: Vito Marcantonio Oral Histories (OH 84) Contains about Marcantonio with various associates, including ...Albar[?], Earl Browder (head of the Communist Party USA from 1934-1945), Brooklyn, N.Y. Congressman Emmanuel Cellar, Eugene Connolly, Leonard "Pop" Covello, Communist Party electoral campaign manager Si Gerson, Ida Hafner, Faye Pasternak, radical writer and literary critic Annette Rubinstein, Peter Sabatino, ...Trilling, and Abraham Unger (an attorney who defended U.S. Communists).

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Vito Marcantonio (1902-1954), who received his law degree from New York University in 1931, was an American Labor Party leader and U.S. Congressmen representing East Harlem, New York, 1935-1937 (as a Republican), and 1939-1951 (American Labor Party), who was also known for generally being politically close to the Communist Party (he opposed U.S. entry into the Korean War), and as an advocate for the rights of Italian Americans, Puerto Ricans, and African Americans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains six United States Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) files obtained under the Freedoom of Information Act and one U.S. State Department document, all pertaining to Vito Marcantonio.
